718913f-a.title: Manhattan: City Hall Park - Old Hall of Records.
718913f-a.text:
City Hall Park: The old Hall of Records located at the S. W. corner of Park Row and Chambers Street. Tho structure was erected in 1735 as a debtors prison. During the Revolution it was used as a prison by the British. It was converted to its present status
in 1840.
July 4, 1860
Gift of Urbrock Collection
American Studios
Na6 281E
718913f-a.folder: City Hall Park & Old Hall of Records., Manhattan, NY

718935f-a.title: Manhattan: City Hall Park -- City Hall
718935f-a.text:
City Hall Park: The City Hall of New York City, erected 1812. The view is northward showing the entrance,
wings and cupola.
About 1870
American Studios
Gift of Urbrock Collection
718935f-a.folder: City Hall Park -- City Hall, Manhattan, NY

718936f-a.title: Manhattan: City Hall Park - City Hall.
718936f-a.text:
City Hall Park: The City Nall, viewed westward towards Broadway. To the left is Murray Street.Buildings shown there are at the N. W. corner.
About 1870
American Studios
Gift of Urbrock Collection
718936f-a.folder: City Hall Park & City Hall., Manhattan, NY

718926f-a.title: Manhattan: City Hall Park.
718926f-a.text:
City Hall Park: A view of the New York City Hall, when the Tweed Ring was building the County Court House. The wooden structure shown atop the latter was placed there, so that the public could not observe the slow progress being made. It cost the City $8,000,000 more than it should
have; Tweed and his Ring taking the money.
About 1875?
Brown Bros.

718909f-a.title: Manhattan: City Hall Park.
718909f-a.text:
City Hall Park: The City Hall decorated for the Dewey
Celebration.
1898
Gift of Urbrock Collection

718927f-a.text:

About 1890
Urbrock Collecti mn

1890:s

718973f-a.title: Manhattan: City Hall Park - City Hall.
718973f-a.text:
City Hall Park: The City Hall viewed westward from Park Row. Beyond are office structures at the N. W. corner of Broadway and Murray Street. These are the Postal Telegraph Building and the Home Life Insurance Co. Building.
About 1900s
Thomas W. Kennedy, photo
Thru Beecher Ogden
Museum Photographers Assn.
718973f-a.folder: City Hall Park & City Hall., Manhattan, NY

718938f-a.title: Manhattan: City Hall Park - N. Hale statue.
718938f-a.text:
City Hall Park: The Nathan Hale statue located in the westerly portion; the Broadway side and viewed northeastward towards Park Row. To the left is the City Hall, to the Nright, the Tribune Building and in the center background, the
Pulitzer (World) Building.
King's Handbook of New York of 1893, page 184 states that this statue by MscMonnies is to be erected here by the
Sons of the Rovolution.
MacMonnies exhibited this in the Paris Salon of 1891 and was awarded a second gold medal, this being the first time
an American sculptor had attained this honor.
Nnte the subway construction in the midground. Evidently the City Hall station and loop of the I.R.T. is in progress.
1900-01
Gift of Urbrock Collection
718938f-a.folder: City Hall Park & N. Hale statue., Manhattan, NY

718900f-a.text:
City Hall Park: A view during the construction of the Subway and showing prominently the City Hall.
April 19, 1901

718903f.title: Manhattan: City Hall Park - [Subway kiosk.]
718903f.text:
City Hall Park:  The subway Kiosk on the northwesterly portion of the Mall that extends thru same from Broadway to Park Row.  At the right is the west wing of the City Hall.  To the left is Chambers Street with the Stewart Building (Sun) and the County House.
1903

718939f-a.title: Manhattan: City Hall Park - [N. Hale statue.]
718939f-a.text:
City Hall Park: The Nathan Hale statue by
MacMonnies, viewed eastward from Broadway and silhoutted against a background consisting of the City Hall. To the right is the Pulitzer (World) Building located on Park Row, the easterly fringe of the Park.
About 1905

718951f-a.title: Manhattan: City Hall Park - [City Hall.]
718951f-a.text:
City Hall Park: A view northward from the easterly
side (Park Row at right) to show the distinctive Municipal Building at Chambers Street. Outlined agwinst the lower portion of same is the Brooklyn 8ridge extension and a Christmas tree. On the right ano left margins respectively are, The City Hall and the
Pulitzer (World) Building.
About 1920

718949f-a.text:
City Hall Park: The neighborhood children taking advantage of the water surrounding "Civic Virtue'. Shown from left to right across the background, are the eastern wing of City Hall, fhic Municipal Building and the elevated pedestrian approach over Park Row, to the Brooklyn Bridge.
August 10, 1926.
P. L. Sperr.

718956f-b.title: Manhattan: City Hall Park - [Fountain - statue of "Civic Virtue".]
718956f-b.text:
City Hall Park: A set of 3 views showing several portions of the park in the midst of winter. No. 1 shows "Civic Virtue;' No. 2 the Nathan Halh statue and No. 3, the trees between the City Hall (left) and the old County Court House (right). This latter view is westward and shows in the background, buildings on the west side of Broadway from Murray (left) to
Warren (right) Streets.
About 1928.

718901f-a.title: Manhattan: City Hall Park - [View of upper downtown skyline.]
718901f-a.text:
New York City: A remarkable view of ugper downtown skyline from th Northeast showing how completely the Woblworth Building, 60 stories, 792 feet high, dominates its surroundings. At the extreme left is the tower of the Sing;er Building; alongside the Woolworth is the far less attractive Transportation Huilding. Far to the right is the New York Telephone Building. The old three cornered building is the old main post office and Federal Building. and the building in the
foreground is the City Hall.
Sept. 1929  Ewing Galloway
718901f-a.folder: City Hall Park & [View of upper downtown skyline.], Manhattan, NY

(1)&.(1) City Hall Park and building in gala attire for reception of Amelia Earhart. 'iss Earhart made an average speed record .181.15 miles an hour over a measured 94 mile course, establishing the first women s international flumht record.4n July b,

718907f-a.title: Manhattan: City Hall Park.
718907f-a.text:
Citw Hall Park: A view of the New York City Hall, located in the center of the Park. Towering edifice shown is the Municipal Building. Between these two, and across the roof of the former is the Hall of Records.
M 36.
W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Writers Project.

718937f.title: Manhattan: City Hall Park - [Fountain - statue of "Civic Virtue".]
718937f.text:
City Hall Park: The MacMonnies statue "Civio Virtue" silhouetted against the City Hall and the Municipal Building.
1938-9
Alexander Alland
This photo is one of a series that appeared in the ptblished volume "Portrait of N. Y.' by Felix Reisenberg and Alex. Alland, IRGV.

718902f.title: Manhattan: City Hall Park - [Fountain - statue of "Civic Virtue"].
718902f.text:
City Hall Park as photographed northeastward from the 24th floor of the New York Telephone &: Telegraph Bldg. Shown is the newly added portion at the apex of this triangular civic zone. This was until recently the site of the old Post Office and Fedoral Bldg. The fountain-statue "Civic Virtue" by MacMonnies still stands in front of the City Hall. This is to be removed to Queens and placed near the new Borough Hall. Note the old "Tweed" County Court House, the new Hall of Records, and the base of the Municipal Bldg. in the background. Broadway is on the left
while on the right is Park Row.
NWEG ~ 320~2
3378
July 2, 1940
Robert A. Knudtsen
221 E. 31st St., N.Y.C.
718902f.folder: City Hall Park & [Fountain & statue of "Civic Virtue"]., Manhattan, NY

718947f-a.title: Manhattan: City Hall Park - [Benjamin Franklin statue.]
718947f-a.text:
1-City Hall Park: Shown is the historic City Hill, as seen from behind the Benjamin Franklin statue.
George L. Balgue  August, 1933
2-Looking northeastward toward the City Hall across the former site of the old Post Office. Across the right wing of the City Hall is the Municipal Building.
P. L. Sperr  April 6, 1940
3-Viewing southwestward across the rear of the City Hall. The dome to the left of the City Hall tower is that of the old Post Office. Shown too is the Woolworth Building and the Transportation Building.
P. L. Sperr  July 4, 1938

718962f-a.title: Manhattan: City Hall Park - City Hall; New York County Court House; New York Tribune; Pulitzer Building; "Printing House Square".
718962f-a.text:
(1)
City Hall Park: A view southeastward from Broadway and showing the rear of the City Hall. The buildings on the far side of the park, form what is known as "Printing House Square", of which the Tribune Tower predominates. Shown on the left, is a portion of the Court House.
Summer 1924.
P. L. Sperr.

(2)
A similar view, and showing the dome of the Pulitzer (New York
World) Building.
June 4, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
NEG #3007

(3)
The same, showing a broader view.
NEG #3008
June 4, 1929
P. L. Sperr.

718906f-b.title: Manhattan: City Hall Park - New York County Court House; Hall of Records.
718906f-b.text:
City Hall Park: A northeasterly view of the City Hall, showing the westerly and southerly sides of same. To the right is the old Brooklyn Bridge train shed over Park Row and to the left, the County Court House. Note the absence of the Pulitzer Building at the right. This was erected in 1889-90 on the site formerly occupied by French's Hotel. A clearance there evidently dates this view.
About 1889
Gift of W. A. Lucas
2) The Hall of REcords in City Hall Park.
Photo by J.J.Corell  About 1900
Fromm P.L.Sperr Collection

718919f-b.title: Manhattan: City Hall Park.
718919f-b.text:
(1)
City Hall Park: A rear view of the City Court, a brownstone structure erected in 1852 on the site of the Rotunda (built in 1816, where works of Art were exhibited). It was occupied by the Court of Special Sessions and in 1879 by the Tax Offices. In the early part of 1929 it was demolished. The Hall of Records, appearing on the right was wrected
in 1903.
November 1923.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
(2)
The same, obscuring the Hall of Records. Structure parti 1ly shown on
the right is the Municipal Building.
October 1928.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
